courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Phonetics and Phonology for English Language Teaching
courses.description: This course covers the basic concepts of phonetics and phonology, with special reference to the sound system and phonological features of the English language. Course content includes: 1) the articulatory and auditory aspects of the English sound system covering both segmental and suprasegmental features; 2) phonological rules 3) phonemic representations and transcription systems; 4) phonological processes underlying speech acquisition and production, and 5) key differences between English and Cantonese phonology. Throughout the course, participants will be guided to consider the pedagogical implications of the concepts covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English Language Teaching and MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, participants should be able to:   
• learn a range of phonemic symbols and vocabulary relevant to English teaching   
• gain a good understanding of English phonemic inventories   
• develop an understanding of phonological rules and processes   
• master the production of English phonemic distinctions and demonstrate how they are produced   
• be able to differentiate the major English accents and describe their distinctive sounds   
• be able to identify difficulties of English learners in Hong Kong and help them deal with pronunciation problems with effective classroom-based methods   
   
(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
courses.course_syllabus:

courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Morphology and Syntax for English Language Teaching
courses.description: This course covers major linguistic concepts of the English morphological and syntactic systems. Participants will be introduced to corpora of spoken and written English for the understanding and conceptualizing of the meaning and forms of words at sentence and discourse levels. Course content includes 1) basic concepts of linguistic treatment of the morpho-syntax of the English language; 2) form and meanings of grammatical/ syntactic and lexical constructions and their relationships with the context of use; 3) syntactic behaviour associated with the word such as tense, aspect, mood, transitivity and voice as well as gender, number, person and case; 4) word knowledge such as denotation, connotation, collocation, lexical sets and semantic fields, sense relations, synonymy, antonymy, hyponymy and meronymy; and 5) implications for teaching and learning.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English Language Teaching and MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic   
1. What is ‘grammar’? Descriptive vs. prescriptive grammars   
2. Approaches to Grammar    
3. Corpus Linguistics   
4. English morphological structure   
5. Nouns and noun phrases   
6. Verbs and verb phrases   
7. Tense, aspect, modality, voice   
8. Adjective, adverb and preposition phrases   
9. Clause and sentence structure   
10. Contrastive analysis, error analysis and interlanguage analysis   
11. Standard English and linguistic variation: implications for language teaching   
   
Contents/ fundamental concepts   
1. The nature of grammar; modern linguistic approaches to the analysis and description of grammar, contrasted with traditional prescriptive approaches.   
2. An overview of some major linguistic approaches to grammar, including formal, functional, cognitive and pedagogical approaches.   
3. Computerized corpora as sources of data on the current state of the language; how to use the British National Corpus and Corpus of Contemporary American English.   
4. Basic categories and concepts in grammar; morphological structure and processes in English.   
5. Properties of nouns (count and mass) and the structure of noun phrases.   
6. Properties of verbs and the structure of verb phrases.   
7. The English tense and aspect system, modal auxiliaries, and transitivity/ voice.   
8. Properties of adjectives, adverbs and prepositions; structure of APs, AvPs and PPs.   
9. The structure of the clause and sentence; main and subordinate clauses; finite and non-finite clauses; relative clauses.   
10. Analyzing learner language: contrasting the grammatical structures of learners’ L1 and L2, their systematic errors, and their internalized language system (interlanguage).   
11. The notions of ‘standard English’ and linguistic variation; their place in society and their implications for language teaching.   
   
(For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Spoken and Written Discourse for English Language Teaching
courses.description: Through a study of discourse conventions of written and spoken language, participants will be introduced to some of the techniques for deconstructing connected speech and writing. Analysis of the structure of discourse, its phonological and orthographic rules, rhetorical structures and pragmatic conventions, will build awareness of how spoken and written language differ in substance and in style, how coherence and cohesion is achieved in speech and in writing, and how speakers and writers address themselves to an audience.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English Language Teaching and MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course participants will have increased their understanding of   
• why discourse is important to English language teaching   
• features of text   
• features of spoken and of written discourse   
They will also be able to   
• analyse genres relevant to their teaching situation   
• evaluate classroom materials as not/ representing authentic discourse, and design improvements where necessary   
• plan a lesson to help students with appropriate features of English discourse   
   
(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)

courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Psychological and Social Perspectives on Language
courses.description: This course will examine the psycholinguistic and sociolinguistic aspects of language. In terms of psycholinguistics, course content will examine the relationship between cognition, cognitive development and language; the stages, processes, and roles that affective factors play in first- and second-language acquisition. This course will also introduce sociolinguistics and study the ways in which groups of people use language, examining the close intertwining between a language and the social context in which it is used. Bilingualism and bilingual education in different contexts will be examined, with particular reference to Hong Kong. Aspects of language variation and dialects, societal bilingualism and multilingualism, language and power, and language policy and planning issues, together with the function of the second language and principles underlying the use of English as a medium of instruction in Hong Kong will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English Language Teaching, MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
courses.course_syllabus:
A. Psycholinguistics, Second Language Acquisition and Bilingualism   
   
This course will examine the psychological aspects of language with an emphasis on second language acquisition.   
- Language and cognition    
- Stages and processes of first- and second-language acquisition   
- Individual and contextual factors contributed to English language development   
- Language learning and identity   
- Implications for teaching a second language in the classroom   
- Function of the second language and principles underlying the use of English as a medium of instruction   
   
B. Sociolinguistics and English as an International Language   
   
This course will explore the relationships between language and society as well as issues relating to English as an International Language.   
   
- Key concepts of sociolinguistics – speech community, diglossia, accent, dialect, language change, language variety, languages in contact and standard languages   
- English as an International Language   
- Linguistic imperialism   
- Varieties of English   
- Relevance of these concepts to the language policy and education in Hong Kong, with additional reference to language planning in other regions of the world.   
   
(For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Literature in English
courses.description: Literature and non-utilitarian texts can introduce living language and bridge the gap between communicative language teaching and culture. Interaction with texts leads to multi-level interpretations of meaning, affective responses, and exploration of cultural and aesthetic values. This course aims to build understanding of the skillful uses and manipulation of language to achieve a variety of effects in prose and poetry as well as in public speeches, advertising and journalism: it aims to open up for the language teacher a diversity of linguistic resources to enrich the curriculum.

courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Language Testing and Assessment
courses.description: This course covers basic principles associated with English language assessment in Hong Kong as well as the implementation and delivery of tests and modes of assessment in Hong Kong. Course covers: 1) important concepts such as reliability, validity, practicality and washback; 2) different test types; 3) test types used in present and past assessment practice – investigating issues such as psychometrically-oriented testing versus a more communicative approach as well as current alternative modes to assessment such as portfolios and school-based assessment; and 4) the setting and marking of tests and other modes of assessment. Participants will be encouraged to consider the different modes of assessment in the light of their own students and developments in the changing assessment scene in Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English Language Teaching
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students will:  
   
• have grasped the major principles underpinning language testing, evaluation and assessment  
   
• have arrived at an understanding of these principles and concepts apply to available tests - tests developed in school exams, public exams, outline tests  
   
• have grasped how to apply these principles and concepts to your own tests and exams  
   
• be able to use the major principles of assessment in the construction and analysis of a test for a particular group of Hong Kong school students  
   
   
(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
courses.course_syllabus:

6. Developing language test items  
   
7. Item analysis in language testing   
   
8. Describing language test results   
   
9. Interpreting language test scores  
   
10. Scoring and developing rating rubric  
   
11. Correlation, reliability, washback & ethics in language testing  
   
12. Assessing reading & vocabulary  
   
13. Assessing listening  
   
14. Assessing writing & grammar  
   
15. Assessing speaking   
   
16. Task-based language assessment

courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Reading and Writing - Teaching and Learning
courses.description: This course will examine the theoretical bases for reading and writing in the light of current perceptions of the processes and strategies involved in the two areas, exploring recent developments and models of second language reading and writing, and the pedagogical impact of these developments. Course participants will be encouraged to reflect on their classroom practice in helping second language learners develop the communicative competence necessary for appropriate and successful written English. The course will also focus on the what and the how of teaching reading and writing.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English Language Teaching, MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, participants should be able to:   
• understand key issues that underlie second language reading and writing;   
• examine and critically reflect on their own reading and writing instruction with reference to recent developments in second language reading and writing; and   
• acquire skills and techniques for planning, teaching and assessing reading and writing.   
   
(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
courses.course_syllabus:
Nature of reading; reading strategies; intensive reading; extensive reading; vocabulary in L2 reading; reader response; critical reading; questioning strategies; formative and summative reading assessment     
Nature of writing; process and product of writing; different approaches to teaching L2 writing; developing writing tasks; genre pedagogy and assessment; creative writing; feedback in L2 writing; formative and summative assessment in L2 writing

courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Information and Communication Technology in English Language Teaching
courses.description: This course covers the application of information and communication technology (ICT) for English language teaching in the light of the history and development of IT generally, and for computer-assisted language learning (CALL) specifically, over the past few decades. The course will look at the development of ICT in terms of the hardware and software available generally (as general-purpose software) or specifically for CALL. The course will examine the use of The Internet for computer-mediated communication such as email, chat programs and bulletin boards. Apart from standalone uses, the course will examine how ICT may be integrated into the broader language curriculum. Other issues covered will be ICT for teachers’ language development, for language research and the use of ICT in assessment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English Language Teaching and MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, participants should be able to (Adapted from TESOL CALL standards):  
Foundational knowledge and skills   
1. Demonstrate knowledge and skills in basic technological concepts and operational competence.   
2. Demonstrate an understanding of a wide range of technology supports for language learning and options for using them in a given setting.    
3. Strive to expand their skill and knowledge base to evaluate, adopt, and adapt emerging technologies throughout their careers.   
4. Use technology in socially and culturally appropriate, legal, and ethical ways.

Integrating technology into curriculum and instruction    
5. Identify and evaluate technological resources and environments for suitability to their teaching context.    
6. Coherently integrate technology into their pedagogical approaches.   
7. Design and manage language learning activities and tasks using technology appropriately to meet curricular goals and objectives.    
8. Use relevant research findings to inform the planning of language learning activities and tasks that involve technology.    
9. Evaluate the effectiveness of specific student uses of technology to enhance teaching and learning.

Using technology in the workplace   
10. Regularly reflect on the intersection of professional practice and technological developments so that they can make informed decisions regarding the use of technology to support language learning and communication.   
11. Apply technology to improve efficiency in preparing for class, grading, and maintaining records.   
   
(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
courses.course_syllabus:
Overview of CALL   
Theoretical foundations of CALL   
Introduction to instructional design    
Evaluation of software / e-learning materials   
ICT for teaching/developing English skills   
E-assessments: Portfolios, Quizzes, and Rubrics   
Managing Teaching through Virtual Learning Environments

courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Professional Development in English Language Teaching
courses.description: The course aims to develop participants' understanding of and experience associated with professional development in teaching English as a second language teaching (ESL). Participants will explore how to apply this knowledge and insight in sustaining their own professional development and to enable them to become more effective language teachers by taking increased responsibility for their own professional development. Topics covered will include: definitions and concepts of professional development; types of professional development, individual differences and their influence on professional development; the theory and practice of professional development; strategies to enhance and support professional development. The course will also examine ways of helping local ESL teachers to engage in professional development with reference to current professional development theories. Course participants are required to engage in a series of professional development activities, with a major focus on improving the teaching and learning of ESL writing, thus enabling them to contribute to an established sustainable professional development model.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English Language Teaching
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, you should:  
   
• have grasped the major principles underpinning professional development (PD) for L2 teachers  
   
• have become familiar with ways to sustain your professional development  
   
• become more effective teachers by taking increased responsibility for your own professional development  
   
• have enhanced your understanding of different methodologies, teaching strategies and techniques available in the English language teaching profession  
   
• be able to evolve your teaching practices in response to the development and learning needs of your students back to your own classroom  
   
• enhance your ability to build a community of learners among students/ teachers  
   
• develop an inquiry ethic that could sustain your professional development throughout your teaching career   
   
   
(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)

5. Innovation in English language teaching

courses.subject: ENLT
courses.title: Project in English Language and Teaching
courses.description: In their second year, with the guidance of a supervisor, students may conduct a small-scale project investigating one significant issue related to English language or to English language teaching. In principle, this project may have the focus of a survey, an experimental study or a case study. Students will have to complete a report of their piece of research according to a standard format. Projects will generally be done on an individual basis, but with the permission of the supervisor it may be possible for up to three students, as a group, to conduct one substantial project.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA English Language Teaching
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:   
1. Demonstrate the application of knowledge and method to the investigation of a specific area within the field of English Language Teaching.   
2. Identify an issue to which solutions and/ or recommendations can be addressed; and produce a written report which sets out clearly the aims, context, content and outcome.   
3. Integrate the skills and knowledge which have been taught in the degree programme with specific application to a topic to produce a well-argued report.   
   
(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
